prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sci Goal: J1430+1339: CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Source: J1430+1339. Observations of the CO(3-2) emission line, traced on the sames size scales as the radio structures.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a set-up to centre the CO(3-2) emission line in a ~2GHz band and placed two ~1GHz bands each side of this. This will allow us to get a good measure of the local continuum at each side of the line, even if the line is broad (~800km/s). We note that we serendipitously obtain coverage of the HCO+ line which traces very dense gas, although it is usually weak. The chosen resolution will allow us to accurately measure emission-line profiles and trace velocity structure even in the narrowest lines we expect to observe (i.e. ~300 km/s). Where appropriate, we will spectrally bin when analysing the data to increase the S/N and measure the properties of the broad lines.

The angular resolution is chosen such that we can directly compare to the smallest radio structures we observe. In this source there are two radio components separated by ~0.5" in the core region (Fig. 3; Harrison et al. 2015). The largest angular scale matches the size of the largest radio structures; the ~6" radio bubbles (Fig. 3; Harrison et al. 2015).

This target has a total IR luminosity of 2d11 Lsol (Harrison et al. 2014). We use two approaches to estimate the CO(3-2) flux. (1) Following the conversion for another z=0.1 type 2 quasar in Sun et al. 2014: L(FIR)/L'CO(3-2)~1100 (Fig. 5). (2) Because this source in Sun et al. 2014 has a FIR luminosity dominated by AGN emission, whilst J1430+1339 appears to be dominated by star formation (Harrison et al. 2014), we expect it to be closer to the conversion typically seen for star forming galaxies and other AGN of comparable L(FIR) i.e., L(FIR)/L'CO(1-0)~40-110 (e.g., Solomon & Vanden Bout 2005; Krips et al. 2012). We then use a typical observed ratio of S[CO(3-2)]/S[CO(1-0)]~5 seen in AGN (e.g., Alatalo et al 2011; Sun et al. 2014; McNamara et al. 2014 Russell et al. 2014).
Reassuringly, a EMIR CO observation of our target is consistent with our expected prediction using the second method (Fig. 5). However, we used the former conservative estimate for our senstivity calculations to be confident of achieving the desired S/N. The numbers provided in the OT are the average of the expected (method 2) and conservative (method 1) values.
Taking our derived L'CO(3-2) values (see above) we estimate a CO(3-2) flux following Solomon and Vanden Bout 2005 and convert this into a peak flux density, by conservatively assuming that the line is as wide as 800km/s (suitable for searching for high-velocity components). This results in peak flux density of S=6-52 mJy (average = 28.7mJy) and S/N=9-74 (average = 41.6) per 30 km/s window at our requested sensitivity. Even for our lower estimate, these data are of sufficient quality to achieve our science goals, even when spatially resolving the emission, as demonstrated by previous ALMA observations of a source that met our selection criteria (Sun et al. 2014; see Fig. 5).
We expect line-widths of FWHM~300-800 km/s (based on the ionised kinematics and similar CO(3-2) observations; e.g. Fig. 2; Harrison et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2014; Fig. 2,5). A spectral resolution of 30km/s (our chosen bandwidth for sensitivity) will be sufficient to trace the velocity shear of narrow components (e.g., tracing any rotating disk) and measuring line-widths and centroids, to the desired accuracy, of individual kinematic components.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sci Goal: J1316+1753: CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Source: J1316+1753. Observations of the CO(3-2) emission line, traced on the sames size scales as the radio structures.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a set-up to centre the CO(3-2) emission line in a ~2GHz band and placed two ~1GHz bands each side of this. This will allow us to get a good measure of the local continuum at each side of the line, even if the line is broad (~800km/s). We note that we serendipitously obtain coverage of the HCO+ line which traces very dense gas, although it is usually weak. The chosen resolution will allow us to accurately measure emission-line profiles and trace velocity structure even in the narrowest lines we expect to observe (i.e. ~300 km/s). Where appropriate, we will spectrally bin when analysing the data to increase the S/N and measure the properties of the broad lines.

The angular resolution is chosen such that we can directly compare to the smallest radio structures we observe. In this source there are two radio jets, at 0.4" and 0.5" away from the core (see Fig. 2). The largest angular scale is larger than the total extent of these compact radio jets so that can measure large-scale structures in addition to the scales of the radio jets.

This target has a total IR luminosity of: 6.5d11 Lsol (Harrison et al. 2014). We use two approaches to estimate the CO(3-2) flux. (1) Following the conversion for another z=0.1 type 2 quasar in Sun et al. 2014: L(FIR)/L'CO(3-2)~1100 (Fig. 5). (2) Because the source in Sun et al 2014 has a FIR luminosity dominated by AGN emission, we also consider the value typically seen for star forming galaxies and other AGN of comparable L(FIR) i.e., L(FIR)/L'CO(1-0)~40-110 (e.g., Solomon & Vanden Bout 2005; Krips et al. 2012). We then use a typical observed ratio of S[CO(3-2)]/S[CO(1-0)]~5 seen in AGN (e.g., Alatalo et al 2011; Sun et al. 2014; McNamara et al. 2014 Russell et al. 2014).
Reassuringly, a EMIR CO observation of one of our targets (J1430+1339) is consistent with our expected prediction using the second method (Fig. 5). However, we used the former conservative estimate for our senstivity calculations to be confident of achieving the desired S/N. The numbers provided in the OT are the average of the expected (method 2) and conservative (method 1) values.
Taking our derived L'CO(3-2) values (see above) we estimate a CO(3-2) flux following Solomon and Vanden Bout 2005 and convert this into a peak flux density, by conservatively assuming that the line is as wide as 800km/s (suitable for searching for high-velocity components). This results in peak flux density of S=6-52 mJy (average = 29.2mJy) and S/N=9-74 (average = 41.6) per 30 km/s window at our requested sensitivity. Even for our lower estimate, these data are of sufficient quality to achieve our science goals, even when spatially resolving the emission, as demonstrated by previous ALMA observations of a source that met our selection criteria (Sun et al. 2014; see Fig. 5).
We expect line-widths of FWHM~300-800 km/s (based on the ionised kinematics and similar CO(3-2) observations; e.g. Fig. 2; Harrison et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2014; Fig. 2,5). A spectral resolution of 30km/s (our chosen bandwidth for sensitivity) will be sufficient to trace the velocity shear of narrow components (e.g., tracing any rotating disk) and measuring line-widths and centroids, to the desired accuracy, of individual kinematic components.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sci Goal: J1010+1413: CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Source: J1010+1413. Observations of the CO(3-2) emission line, traced on the sames size scales as the radio structures.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a set-up to centre the CO(3-2) emission line in a ~2GHz band and placed two ~1GHz bands each side of this. This will allow us to get a good measure of the local continuum at each side of the line, even if the line is broad (~800km/s). We note that we serendipitously obtain coverage of the HCO+ line which traces very dense gas, although it is usually weak. The chosen resolution will allow us to accurately measure emission-line profiles and trace velocity structure even in the narrowest lines we expect to observe (i.e. ~300 km/s). Where appropriate, we will spectrally bin when analysing the data to increase the S/N and measure the properties of the broad lines.

The angular resolution is chosen such that we can directly compare to the smallest radio structures we observe. In this source there are structures, ~1" away from the core and a ~1" structure located 3" north of the core (see Fig. 2). The largest angular scale covers the total extent of the radio emission so that can measure large-scale structure in addition to scales of the radio structures.

This target has a total IR luminosity of: 1.8d12 Lsol (Harrison et al. 2014). We use two approaches to estimate the CO(3-2) flux. (1) Following the conversion for another z=0.1 type 2 quasar in Sun et al. 2014: L(FIR)/L'CO(3-2)~1100 (Fig. 5). (2) Because the source in Sun et al 2014 has a FIR luminosity dominated by AGN emission, which does not appear to be the case for this target (Harrison et al. 2014) we also consider the value typically seen for star forming galaxies and other AGN of comparable L(FIR) i.e., L(FIR)/L'CO(1-0)~40-110 (e.g., Solomon & Vanden Bout 2005; Krips et al. 2012). We then use a typical observed ratio of S[CO(3-2)]/S[CO(1-0)]~5 seen in AGN (e.g., Alatalo et al 2011; Sun et al. 2014; McNamara et al. 2014 Russel et al. 2014). Reassuringly, a EMIR CO observation of one of our targets (J1430+1339) is consistent with our expected prediction using the second method (Fig. 5). However, we used the former conservative estimate for our senstivity calculations to be confident of achieving the desired S/N. The numbers provided in the OT are the average of the expected (method 2) and conservative (method 1) values.
Taking our derived L'CO(3-2) values (see above) we estimate a CO(3-2) flux following Solomon and Vanden Bout 2005 and convert this into a peak flux density, by conservatively assuming that the line is as wide as 800km/s (suitable for searching for high-velocity components). This results in peak flux density of S=10-82 mJy (average = 45.8mJy) and S/N=11-90 (average = 50.9) per 30 km/s window at our requested sensitivity. Even for our lower estimate, these data are of sufficient quality to achieve our science goals, even when spatially resolving the emission, as demonstrated by previous ALMA observations of a source that met our selection criteria (Sun et al. 2014; see Fig. 5).
We expect line-widths of FWHM~300-800 km/s (based on the ionised kinematics and similar CO(3-2) observations; e.g. Fig. 2; Harrison et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2014; Fig. 2,5). A spectral resolution of 30km/s (our chosen bandwidth for sensitivity) will be sufficient to trace the velocity shear of narrow components (e.g., tracing any rotating disk) and measuring line-widths and centroids, to the desired accuracy, of individual kinematic components.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a set-up to centre the CO(3-2) emission line in a ~2GHz band and placed two ~1GHz bands each side of this. This will allow us to get a good measure of the local continuum at each side of the line, even if the line is broad (~800km/s). Where appropriate, we will spectrally bin when analysing the data to increase the S/N and measure the properties of the broad lines.

The angular resolution is chosen such that we can directly compare to the smallest radio structures we observe. In this source there are ~0.8" structures, one at ~3" north of the core and one at ~1" sourth of the core (see Fig. 2). The largest angular scale covers the total extent of the radio emission so that can measure large-scale structure in addition to the small-scale structure on scales of the radio structures.

This target has a total IR luminosity of: 6.6d11 Lsol (Harrison et al. 2014). We use two approaches to estimate the CO(3-2) flux. (1) Following the conversion for another z=0.1 type 2 quasar in Sun et al. 2014: L(FIR)/L'CO(3-2)~1100 (Fig. 5). However, we used the former conservative estimate for our senstivity calculations to be confident of achieving the desired S/N. The numbers provided in the OT are the average of the expected (method 2) and conservative (method 1) values.
Taking our derived L'CO(3-2) values (see above) we estimate a CO(3-2) flux following Solomon and Vanden Bout 2005 and convert this into a peak flux density, by conservatively assuming that the line is as wide as 800km/s (suitable for searching for high-velocity components). This results in peak flux density of S=6.5-54 mJy (average = 30.2mJy) and S/N=9-74 (average = 41.4) per 30 km/s window at our requested sensitivity. Even for our lower estimate, these data are of sufficient quality to achieve our science goals, even when spatially resolving the emission, as demonstrated by previous ALMA observations of a source that met our selection criteria (Sun et al. 2014; see Fig. 5).
We expect line-widths of FWHM~300-800 km/s (based on the ionised kinematics and similar CO(3-2) observations; e.g. Fig. 2; Harrison et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2014; Fig. 2,5). A spectral resolution of 30km/s (our chosen bandwidth for sensitivity) will be sufficient to trace the velocity shear of narrow components (e.g., tracing any rotating disk) and measuring line-widths and centroids, to the desired accuracy, of individual kinematic components.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a set-up to centre the CO(3-2) emission line in a ~2GHz band and placed two ~1GHz bands each side of this. The angular resolution is chosen such that we can directly compare to the smallest radio structures we observe. In this source there are radio structures, separated by 0.5" (see Fig. 2). The largest angular scale covers over the total extent of the radio emission so that can measure large-scale structure in addition to the small-scale structure on scales of the radio structures.

This target has a total IR luminosity of: 4.2d11 Lsol (Harrison et al. 2014). We use two approaches to estimate the CO(3-2) flux. (1) Following the conversion for another z=0.1 type 2 quasar in Sun et al. 2014: L(FIR)/L'CO(3-2)~1100 (Fig. 5). Even for our lower estimate, these data are of sufficient quality to achieve our science goals, even when spatially resolving the emission, as demonstrated by previous ALMA observations of a source that met our selection criteria (Sun et al. 2014; see Fig. 5).
We expect line-widths of FWHM~300-800 km/s (based on the ionised kinematics and similar CO(3-2) observations; e.g. Fig. 2; Harrison et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2014; Fig. 2,5). A spectral resolution of 30km/s (our chosen bandwidth for sensitivity) will be sufficient to trace the velocity shear of narrow components (e.g., tracing any rotating disk) and measuring line-widths and centroids, to the desired accuracy, of individual kinematic components.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sci Goal: J0945+1737: CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Source: J0945+1737. Observations of the CO(3-2) emission line, traced on the sames size scales as the radio structures.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have chosen a set-up to centre the CO(3-2) emission line in a ~2GHz band and placed two ~1GHz bands each side of this. This will allow us to get a good measure of the local continuum at each side of the line, even if the line is broad (~800km/s). We note that we serendipitously obtain coverage of the HCO+ line which traces very dense gas, although it is usually weak. The chosen resolution will allow us to accurately measure emission-line profiles and trace velocity structure even in the narrowest lines we expect to observe (i.e. ~300 km/s). Where appropriate, we will spectrally bin when analysing the data to increase the S/N and measure the properties of the broad lines.

The angular resolution is chosen such that we can directly compare to the smallest radio structures we observe. In this source there is a ~0.6" radio structure located ~1" East of the core (see Fig. 2). The largest angular scale covers the total extent of the radio emission so that can measure large-scale structure in addition to the small-scale structure on scales of the radio structures.

This target has a total IR luminosity of: 1.0d12 Lsol (Harrison et al. 2014). We use two approaches to estimate the CO(3-2) flux. (1) Following the conversion for another z=0.1 type 2 quasar in Sun et al. 2014: L(FIR)/L'CO(3-2)~1100 (Fig. 5). (2) Because the source in Sun et al 2014 has a FIR luminosity dominated by AGN emission, which does not appear to be the case for this target (Harrison et al. 2014) we also consider the value typically seen for star forming galaxies and other AGN of comparable L(FIR) i.e., L(FIR)/L'CO(1-0)~40-110 (e.g., Solomon & Vanden Bout 2005; Krips et al. 2012). We then use a typical observed ratio of S[CO(3-2)]/S[CO(1-0)]~5 seen in AGN (e.g., Alatalo et al 2011; Sun et al. 2014; McNamara et al. 2014 Russell et al. 2014). Reassuringly, a EMIR CO observation of one of our targets (J1430+1339) is consistent with our expected prediction using the second method (Fig. 5). However, we used the former conservative estimate for our senstivity calculations to be confident of achieving the desired S/N. The numbers provided in the OT are the average of the expected (method 2) and conservative (method 1) values.
Taking our derived L'CO(3-2) values (see above) we estimate a CO(3-2) flux following Solomon and Vanden Bout 2005 and convert this into a peak flux density, by conservatively assuming that the line is as wide as 800km/s (suitable for searching for high-velocity components). This results in peak flux density of S=14-113 mJy (average = 63.1mJy) and S/N=15-125 (average = 70.1) per 30 km/s window at our requested sensitivity. Even for our lower estimate, these data are of sufficient quality to achieve our science goals, even when spatially resolving the emission, as demonstrated by previous ALMA observations of a source that met our selection criteria (Sun et al. 2014; see Fig. 5).
We expect line-widths of FWHM~300-800 km/s (based on the ionised kinematics and similar CO(3-2) observations; e.g. Fig. 2; Harrison et al. 2014; Sun et al. 2014; Fig. 2,5). A spectral resolution of 30km/s (our chosen bandwidth for sensitivity) will be sufficient to trace the velocity shear of narrow components (e.g., tracing any rotating disk) and measuring line-widths and centroids, to the desired accuracy, of individual kinematic components.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: An outstanding issue of galaxy formation models is exactly how quasars interact with their host galaxies and the impact that this has. We are constraining the prevalence, properties and impact of outflows by combining multiple observational datasets of representative sources. We propose for CO observations of 6 z~0.1 optical quasars drawn from our well-constrained parent sample. We have identified ionised outflows and radio jets/bubbles on kpc scales in these sources. Contrary to some predictions this shows these processes are important for sources with moderate radio luminosities and outside of cluster environments. Our proposed ALMA observations will provide crucial information on the molecular gas. We will measure the distribution and velocity structure, comparing to the ionised gas and radio structures. We will establish if radio jets/bubbles are accelerating/destroying molecular gas and if the outflows are (not) predominantly in an ionised form. These data will provide insight into how quasars couple energy to their host galaxies. Furthermore, we will test prescriptions of galaxy formation models, including directly to the EAGLE cosmological simulation based in our institute
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: We note that one target we would have observed was observed in Cycle 1 (2012.1.00797.S). These data demonstrate the feasibility of our proposed experiment (see justification) and will be combined with the proposed data to create a sample of 7 objects.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Catolica of Chile, Pontifica University
Department of Physics and Astronomy, Sheffield, University of
